	<item>
		<title>Need a Holiday?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/need-holiday/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 10:56:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=332</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_333" align="alignright" width="224"]<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/chris-on-slopes.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-333 " alt="On the slopes in Verbier" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/chris-on-slopes-224x300.jpg" width="224" height="300" /></a> On the slopes in Verbier[/caption]
<h1>Working hard is great, but you also need some time out!</h1>
I'm sure everyone can agree with me on this one? We all work hard and we all need to get away, whether that be on a family holiday, weekend away or simply some time at home, it's just as important as working hard. I can speak from experience on this one and can clearly remember being at University, doing 12 hour Ambulance shifts (as part of my placement) and running a business over 100 miles away... People kept telling me to take some time out, not least my family and it wasn't until they booked a family holiday for me, that I realised just how much I needed to get away for a break.

It is sometime hard to realise that you do need a break, you get so deep into what your doing and keeping up to speed with what's happening, whether you have reached your goals, monthly targets, ongoing projects - the list is endless.

My advice is simple and something I have been doing for the past couple of years - <strong>book breaks in advance!</strong>

... This has reminded me to book some holidays!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>My Day out in a Private Jet</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/day-private-jet/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 12:34:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=385</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/jet.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-386 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/jet-300x229.png" alt="jet" width="300" height="229" /></a>I have always wanted to go on my own Private Jet, but I didn't think it would be at the age of 22, wearing my Paramedic uniform...</h2>
My team and I at <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> are used to medical repatriations, normally theses are performed for an array of insurance companies and take place in private aircraft or commercial flights with medical escort. However, just a few days after new year the operations team at Jigsaw Medical took a phone call from a private patient who was ill abroad and without travel insurance. The prospective client enquired about our <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/emergency-ambulance-service.html">medical repatriation</a> services and whether we could help get her home for medical treatment in the UK…

Normally our "Private Jets" are old propeller aircraft specifically used for air repatriations and therefore not really that glamorous... However for this job (due to the lack of insurance) we had to charter a 'normal' private jet from our friends at <a href="http://www.saxonair.com/">Saxon Air.</a>

Obviously, as the 'boss' and a Paramedic myself, it was left to me to carry out this job (along with a colleague Kathryn, who is also a Paramedic). Believe it or not, <strong>it was cheaper to get a private jet</strong> than it would have been to drive by land ambulance.
<h3>In just under 3 hours, our shift on our RRV (or plane) was done and the patient was successfully back in a UK hospital!</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How fast should you grow your business?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/fast-grow-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 14:16:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=404</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_405" align="alignleft" width="300"]<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/beanbag-room.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-405 " alt="beanbag-room" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/beanbag-room-300x224.png" width="300" height="224" /></a> My thinking room @ Jigsaw House[/caption]
<h3>I for one would love to grow my businesses as quickly as possible... but you can't afford to run out of money...</h3>
This is a question I have asked myself a number of times and have often discussed with my family and friends. The reality is, nobody seems to know the definitive answer but I can say - its a very important factor. I used to not worry about cash flow at all and just deal with it as the issues arose, however our ethos as a business is to pay our bills on time and get paid on time (easier said than done!). I am very lucky to have a supportive family and a supportive bank manager - all of which help when it comes to cash flow.

Growth of a business and its cash flow go hand-in-hand, good businesses grow when they have lots of cash; through investing in their workforce, assets and processes (and of course they stop when they don't have any free cash!). However, not-so-good businesses will pay their shareholders handsomely and not re-invest. <strong>No investment = No growth.</strong>

I will always remember learning my lesson in cash flow, I clearly remember my dad telling me not to buy some new equipment (which was not vital) as I would <em>"run out of money"</em>... and guess what happened. Since then, we keep a close eye on our cash flow in both businesses, our accountant sits in our main office which really helps when it comes to keeping on top of the finances, but best of all Abi (my Sales Manager) sits opposite me and keeps an even closer eye on spending (she is from Yorkshire)!
<h2>So whats the answer?</h2>
Plan to grow when you have plenty of cash in the bank, not when you do not. Be strategic in the growth and <strong><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/dont-become-busy-fools/">don't become busy fools</a>.</strong>
<h2></h2>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Don&#039;t become &#039;busy fools&#039;</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/dont-become-busy-fools/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 14:46:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=418</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/8-arm-salesman.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-419 alignright" alt="Travailler plus..." src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/8-arm-salesman-300x271.jpg" width="300" height="271" /></a>I meet a lot of busy fools in business, most of them are our competitors in <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a>! But what is a busy fool and how can you avoid becoming one of them...</h1>
There are so many opportunities to be a busy fool in today’s business environment, if you can relate to this - perhaps now is a great time to give yourself a shake and set some New Year’s resolutions to ensure you drop the “fool” and just stay busy....
<h2><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Saying "YES!"</span></h2>
Richard Branson is known as "Mr Yes" at <a href="http://www.virgin.com/">Virgin</a> and although I agree there is a lot to be said about saying 'Yes' (and I do this myself most of the time), you also need to know when to say NO! This is more relevent when it comes to business and I can best relate to this in our work with Jigsaw Medical and <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/event-medical-cover.html">event medical cover</a>. The event cover industry is full of 'cheap and cheerful companies' which we do not compete with at Jigsaw Medical, we stick to what we are good at - at the higher end of the spectrum, motor sport, festivals and the like. We used to say Yes to everyone - and guess what we became...
<h3>... Make sure you find your niche and stick to it.</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Making money from your online presence </title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/making-money-online-presence/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 15:59:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=423</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/map_of_the_internet_by_tophthetomboy-d348wf0.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-424 alignleft" alt="map_of_the_internet_by_tophthetomboy-d348wf0" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/map_of_the_internet_by_tophthetomboy-d348wf0-300x165.jpg" width="300" height="165" /></a>What's this? The internet?</h1>
Companies large and small are getting used to fact that you <strong>need</strong> to have a web site. But just having a web site doesn't guarantee a company an increase in business--if those millions of potential customers don't happen to stumble on it, you're spinning your virtual wheels... Obviously with <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk">eJigsaw</a> you will have gathered that I love the internet and realising its potential to our businesses. Although I am a believer that businesses can survive without a website, its only a small number of sectors where this is possible. The recent Google advert very powerfully re-enforced the power of the internet and a fantastic <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/website-design-chester/">website design</a>.
<h2>The search engines</h2>
Those of you who know what we do at eJigsaw and what has partially made the success of Jigsaw Medical so far is that we have some very powerful search engine marketing, which is all ethical, organic and in-house. For example, our Jigsaw Medical website is optimised by our friends at eJigsaw for many search terms, including <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">first aid training</a>. When we talk about businesses surviving without an internet presence, I strongly feel that without our websites, social media and range of internet marketing streams - we would not be where we are today.
<h2>What do you need to see a return from your online investment?</h2>
Obviously we would be bias in who you should use to provide this service to your business, because I think the team at eJigsaw would take some beating! But from a personal point of view, you need to look at building your online presence by using the following tips!
<ol>
	<li><strong>A great website design - </strong>This is the fundamental part of your internet presence, its your online office, just think of it as your house, but online.</li>
	<li><strong>Search engine marketing</strong> - Once you have a great website for your business, it needs to be found by these millions of potential customers, having a great SEO company will help you get found on Google and other search engines.</li>
	<li><strong>Branding -</strong> Your website and everything you do should be focused around your brand!</li>
	<li><strong>Social Media -</strong> You need to be on Twitter, Facebook Business and Google + (at the least)</li>
	<li><strong>Active Blog</strong> - Make sure you have an active blog which is interesting (unlike mine) and provides a growth in your website content.</li>
	<li><strong>DELEGATE</strong> - Do not spend to much time trying to do this yourself - Hire <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/">eJigsaw</a>!</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The right people in your business</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/right-people-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Feb 2014 11:12:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=430</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">"The right people for your business are those who can do their job when they don’t feel like it. The wrong people are those who can’t do their job when they do feel like it."</p>
</blockquote>
<h2></h2>
<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/person-with-question-mark-backgrounds-wallpapers.jpg"><img class="wp-image-431 alignleft" alt="person-with-question-mark-backgrounds-wallpapers" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/person-with-question-mark-backgrounds-wallpapers-300x198.jpg" width="300" height="198" /></a></h2>
<h2>Getting the right people, at the right time, into the right positions within your organisation, is critical to it's success...</h2>
I am strong believer that it is the people who make a business good, or bad. I recently made one of our suppliers an ex-supplier, as I felt their customer service ethos was not in line with what we expect as a customer, but I also didn't want them to be an instrumental part of our business. In the same token, because it's the people who make your business, it's also the people who make (or break) theirs. In my view suppliers and customers should be treated in the same way, we need both of them to provide an excellent service to our clients, if someone in their business letting that down - we would go elsewhere. The same can be said for our businesses, if <em>people</em> don't like our <em>people</em>, this will reflect badly on our business - however good we may be.... <strong>you might be getting the drift about the whole 'people' thing!</strong>
<h2>Customer service</h2>
<strong>Not everyone will be great at dealing with customers</strong>, <strong>but that's okay providing that is not their role!</strong><strong> </strong>Getting the right people in the right place is the aim of the game, those who are customer facing should be organised, approachable, problem solving and have a passion for great customer service. For example, in <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> our clinicains need to be skilled, professional and naturally caring, but also our design team in <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/">eJigsaw</a> also need to be skilled, professional and caring. Lots of core attributes will transfer over - whatever the role!
<h2></h2>
<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/job-interview-answers-questions.jpg"><img class="wp-image-436 alignright" alt="job-interview-answers-questions" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/job-interview-answers-questions-300x196.jpg" width="209" height="136" /></a></h2>
<h2>How to get the right people...</h2>
Now there is a question... I'm confident that nobody would actually know the answer to this one (I'm just 22 but have already had to "restructure" one of my organisation's to ensure we maintained the right people, in the right places).... But here are some top-tips!
<ul>
	<li><strong>Use a professional HR company</strong> to help with the nitty gritty - we use <a href="https://www.peninsula-online.com/">Peninsula Business Services </a>in all of our businesses, they are friendly, realistic and professional</li>
	<li><strong>Use Psychometric profiling</strong> to uncover the 'real' person behind the interview - we use <a href="http://yenomassociates.co.uk/">Yenom Associates</a> for all of our Occupational Personality Profiling (OPP)</li>
	<li><strong>Take your time</strong> in choosing the right person, they may not be the first person you meet or interview, but they may be filling in your online application!</li>
	<li><strong>Don't use recruitment agencies </strong>for permanent positions - there are some exceptions to this rule, but generally <strong>you</strong> know who you want on <strong>your</strong> <strong>team</strong>!</li>
</ul>
<h2>Remember! The people you employ will almost certainly be the difference between success, and failure... but also the difference between an energetic and positive working life - or a hard one!</h2>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>430</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[right-people-business]]></wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Keeping employees happy</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/keeping-employees-happy/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Feb 2014 11:42:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=444</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Following on from my Blog post yesterday regarding having <a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/right-people-business/">the right people in your business</a>, I found a great info-graphic from Plantronics, explaining more...</h3>
<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/secret-keeping-employees-happy.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-445" alt="secret-keeping-employees-happy" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/secret-keeping-employees-happy.jpg" width="610" height="2256" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Concentrate on your business, not your competitors</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/concentrate-on-you/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 16:21:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=448</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_451" align="alignright" width="351"]<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/look-at-competitors.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-451 " alt="Don't spend all of your time spying..." src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/look-at-competitors.jpg" width="351" height="359" /></a> Don't spend all of your time spying...[/caption]
<h1>If you concentrate more on what your competitors are doing, your own business will <span style="text-decoration: underline;">fail</span>.</h1>
<h3>... A bold claim, but one which I genuinely do believe in.</h3>
There is a small flip side to this which is that it is important to know what they are doing, but like everything - there is a limit to how much snooping you need to do! I am fairly confident I <strong>know</strong> exactly what our competitors in <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> and <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/">eJigsaw</a> are doing, but I do not spend time <strong>concentrating</strong> on what they are doing, or worse, 'spying' on them. This is the important difference which you need to keep an eye on...
<h3>Do you look at your competitors Facebook, website or twitter etc EACH DAY?</h3>
If your answer is yes, then to be brutally honest, you need to have a look at your own Facebook, twitter and concentrate on that! Don't get me wrong, a quarterly look at what they are up to - or even a reactive snoop is not a problem and, like I say, <strong>knowing</strong> what they are up to is important, <strong>concentrating</strong> on them is likely to put your own business onto the path of failure.
<h3>So, what's the problem?</h3>
There are a few problems really, the main one being your lack of focus and effort on your own business - which should worry you. But other issues in concentrating too much on your competitors may also be the decrease in morale for yourself, and your team. By all means if they do something you think is great - make it better, don't copy it and start a 'cat fight' - work with your team, your brand and your business - and make it better!
<h3>How do you know?</h3>
Good question - well I may only be 22 years-old, but already I have learnt this important lesson. I employed a manager in one of our divisions who was fixated on our competitors, he would text me, call me and email me about what they were up to and why... He would create negativity in the team by telling them all about how our competitors are doing this, and that - He was not looking closer to home at what <strong>we</strong> could do to make our service better and ultimately make them suffer. Needless to say, the person in question is no longer in my team..
<h3>And guess what - we focused on us and <em>'kept an eye' on what they were up to</em> -<em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> not the other way round</span>.</em></h3>
<h3>The end result = We doubled our turnover in that division &amp; lesson learnt!</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>448</wp:post_id>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What&#039;s your Goal?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/whats-goal/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2014 08:05:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=460</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/image.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-461 alignright" alt="image" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/image.jpg" width="300" height="239" /></a>You should have goals, whether they are just a goal for Monday,a goal for the month or a goal further ahead... You need them.

I am a keen believer in goals and lining up a target, this goes for business and also personally. My business goals come in all shapes and sizes and focus on different aspects of my businesses.
<h2>Tell your team</h2>
Don't forget - if your goal involves your team (which I'm sure it will), you need to share it with them, so they can also focus on helping you reach it!

Don't just keep it to yourself!
<h3>Have a Happy Monday and get some goals set!</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>460</wp:post_id>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Don&#039;t just copy...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/find-gap/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 22 Mar 2014 09:42:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=464</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I often see startup businesses and I sometimes think they have missed the point somewhere. Copying an existing business will not work - unless you take the bits they are not doing well at, and make them better in your business.

There are thousands of event medical and first aid training providers in the UK, there are also thousands of design &amp; hosting companies in the UK, so why are we succeeding? We have simply taken what the industry doesn't do very well, and made it 10 times better.

So my Saturday tip is this.... Don't just copy someone else's idea, take the industry by the reins, and <strong>make it better! </strong>

Remember: "it's about being different"]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>464</wp:post_id>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Cloud Computing for Entrepreneurs &amp; Your Business</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/cloud-computing-entrepreneurs-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 Mar 2014 08:45:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=475</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/eJigsaw-Cloud.png"><img class="wp-image-474 alignright" alt="eJigsaw-Cloud" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/eJigsaw-Cloud.png" width="328" height="195" /></a>The term “<strong>Cloud Computing</strong>” has become quite a perplexing and mystical phrase for many people. A lot of entrepreneurs know they should be looking into what the cloud can do for their company but aren’t certain of where to begin. If you’re struggling to get your head around what <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/cloud-hosting/">cloud computing</a> actually is, then check out our website for <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/">eJigsaw</a>....

The market over the next 5 years will change dramatically as the scepticism and concerns over moving to the cloud reduce and more and more people and businesses embrace the technology. Evidence suggests that the global cloud market could reach £150 billion by 2020<strong>.</strong> <strong></strong>

Firstly entrepreneurs need a product that specifically meets their business needs – At eJigsaw we have invested a lot of our resources into creating a great value product that meets the needs of our direct customers, many of whom are entrepreneurs. The result is our market leading <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/cloud-hosting/">Cloud Server</a> range.

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/cloud-computing-datatrend.jpg"><img class="wp-image-478 alignleft" alt="cloud-computing-datatrend" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/cloud-computing-datatrend.jpg" width="223" height="167" /></a>In my businesses, I want to keep overheads down, yet have the right solution to grow my business. In-house IT is extreemly expensive, especially when you are growing. Do you order the £10,000 server for today or the £15,000 as your growing, and may need this capacity tomorrow. Cloud hosting lets easily alter the capacity of your servers to meet the changing needs of your businesses. For instance, businesses with websites on cloud servers can schedule upgrades to cope with peaks in traffic. This ensures sites don’t go down or suffer from poor performance when they’re busy... When was the last time you saw 'Dragons Den' and Googled the company who was pitching, only to find their website was 'down'? It always confuses me (and I do often email them or even Tweet them) to promote our solid hosting services at <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk">eJigsaw</a>. Its most likely the best advertising they will ever get and nobody can see their website!...
<h3>Hosting is important, not least for entrepreneurs... so get yourself in The eJigsaw Cloud and <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/contact">contact</a> my awesome hosting team today and keep your business online!</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Let&#039;s Strike!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/lets-strike/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Apr 2014 11:18:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=481</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>...Okay, this may turn into a slightly controversial post - so I will keep it brief and put it out there...</h2>
<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/r-ONTARIO-TEACHERS-STRIKE-large570.jpg"><img class="wp-image-482 alignright" alt="r-ONTARIO-TEACHERS-STRIKE-large570" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/r-ONTARIO-TEACHERS-STRIKE-large570.jpg" width="400" height="167" /></a>Does striking get you anywhere? - that's the question!

When I was a student Paramedic, it was clear to me that unions sill very much existed and were campaigning for people to join up (for the record, I didn't as I personally don't believe in them). I am not convinced that striking is the way to be heard, its certainly the way to get some (bad) press and upset the nation, but I don't think its the way to put your point across in modern times.

Most recently we saw teachers strike to get their views heard and whilst I agree with what they are saying, I still feel that people should find an alternative way to get their own way! Putting the education of the nations children at risk by doing it - is probably not the most favored move!
<h3>Whats the alternative?</h3>
If a member of my team were to be upset or even close to thinking about 'striking' I would be upset that they haven't approached me to discuss it... It's a little different in the fact that my team is small compared with the nations teachers! However, there is always someones office door you can knock on to get your opinions heard, without the banner printing costs and disruption!

Striking often results in more harm than good and I think that's whats happened in the latest teaching strike. There’s got to be a better way to get the opinions of both sides heard and resolved, rather than neglecting the education of our young people<strong>.. We are all human after all!</strong> <strong></strong>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>481</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[lets-strike]]></wp:post_name>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>5 Ways to Motivate Your Team</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/5-ways-motivate-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Apr 2014 16:33:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=485</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/teamwork.png"><img class="size-full wp-image-486 alignright" alt="teamwork" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/teamwork.png" width="434" height="261" /></a>1. Lead with Enthusiasm &amp; Optimism</strong> – Negativity and fear are likely knocking your team off balance and it’s time to regroup, refocus, and unite to create a winning mindset, culture and positive team environment. Now, more than ever, is a time for positive leadership. Now is the time to uplift, encourage and inspire your teams. When your folks talk about the challenges, you talk about the opportunities. When others talk about why they can’t succeed, you give them every reason why they can. So often the difference between success and failure is belief and as a positive leader you need to inspire this belief and optimism in your team.
<p align="left"><strong>2. Don't Just Hide in Your Office</strong> – You need to be humble and hungry. Humble in that you seek to learn, grow, and improve every day, and hungry with a passion to work harder than everyone else. Now is not a time to be barricaded in your office. Now is a time to be in their with your team, leading, working, and building a successful future.</p>
<strong>3. Set Goals &amp; Share Them</strong> – You should have goals, whether they are just a goal for Monday, a goal for the month or a goal further ahead… You need them. I am a keen believer in goals and lining up a target, this goes for business and also personally. My business goals come in all shapes and sizes and focus on different aspects of my businesses. Don’t forget – if your goal involves your team (which it will), you need to share it with them, so they can also focus on helping you reach it!
<p align="left"><strong>4. Share a Positive Vision</strong> – Rally your team around a positive vision for the road ahead. Instead of being disappointed about where you are, decide to be optimistic about where you are going. Vision helps you and your team see the road ahead and it gives you something meaningful and valuable to strive towards. Discuss where you have been, where you are going and why you are going there. Martin Luther King Jr. had a dream/vision and he changed the world with it. Share your dream and improve your organization with it. After all, if you think your best days are behind you, they are. <span style="text-decoration: underline;">If you think your best days are ahead of you, they are.</span></p>
<p align="left"><strong>5. Teach Your Team to Be Heroes, Not Victims</strong> – Heroes and victims get knocked down. The distinction between the two groups lies in the fact that heroes get back up while victims simply give up. Help your team to realise that they are not victims of circumstance. Rather, remind them that they have a high level of control—in other words, they have a significant influence over how things turn out - because they should!. Life is a story, and the story we tell ourselves and the role we play determines the quality and direction of our life. The most successful people and teams are able to overcome adversity by telling themselves a more positive story than the rest.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>485</wp:post_id>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Starting Out In Business</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/starting-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Apr 2014 11:30:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=490</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/business-plan-xs.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-491 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/business-plan-xs.jpg" alt="Business plan" width="467" height="310" /></a>Instead of waiting for someone else to hire you, why not set up a company and employ yourself?</h2>
It would be reasonable to say that starting your own business is not for everyone... it involves a great deal of hard work and risk, but also a massive potential reward. Many people who are looking at starting their own business really don't know where to begin. There is some guidence on the internet for you, including some help from the government on '<a href="https://www.gov.uk/starting-up-a-business/start-with-an-idea">Starting your own business</a>'.

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>But here are my four (and a bit) top tips...</strong></span>

<strong>1. A bad time is the right time... </strong>It is tricky to start a business at any time - not just during a recession - but their particular business idea is so niche, so focussed, and so special that they shrug off the gloom and just get on with it. The upside of starting a business during a downturn is that things can only get better as the economic climate improves, and you will have learnt an awful lot in the difficult times that you can use in the easier ones.

<strong>2. The right idea... </strong>For those of you who have seen <a href="http://www.ejigsaw.co.uk/">eJigsaw</a> - "it's about being different". Your idea either needs to be unique or something which is different from your prospective competitors, don't just copy someone else - do a better job!

<strong>3. The tools... </strong>Most homes and most students are already equipped with quite a lot of the tools any business needs to reach a worldwide audience from day one. Computer power is so cheap that many school or university leavers have their own machines, with processing power unimaginable a few years ago. Laptops can edit sound or movies, design software, and keep track of all the details of a start-up business at minimal cost. Internet connectivity allows a start-up entrepreneur to collaborate with video conferencing at almost no cost, an extraordinary breakthrough.

<strong>4. The people... </strong>Okay, it will not matter immediately (unless you are employing someone immediately) - but don't forget that people make a massive difference to your business and its success. Have the right people in your team and work with the best suppliers and support networks to make it easier for you and better for you business!

<strong>... OH! And don't forget 'cash is king', make sure you keep an eye on that cash flow! Have a look at my blog on <a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/fast-grow-business/">'how quick should you grow your business'</a>
</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>490</wp:post_id>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[491]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A Big Milestone...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/big-milestone/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 Jun 2014 06:56:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=497</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I recently hit a big milestone in my journey so far, something which I didn't see happening so quickly...

I was once told that there 'was no money in our industry', I was told this by a chap who ended up selling me his business - and in the year following our acquisition we managed to double its revenue... I suppose that alone refuted his comment and made me more confident than ever that there was huge potential for a professional and forward thinking business in the sector.

Recently however we have reached this milestone which I am very proud of along with the whole team - we were honoured to be asked to provide services for one of the worlds largest sporting events. Not only is this prestigious, it's also a single weekend contract which will see a turnover more than 2.5 times that seen in a whole year of this chaps company (before we bought it) - the same chap who told me some "wise words" and claimed there was no money in it.

Was he right? ....Well yes, there was no money in it for him, or his ethos. But it goes to show that a company with the right ethos and people can make it happen in a very short space of time...

So some wise words for today - "If you think you won't or you think you will, you're right - so be positive, change &amp; make it happen!"]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>497</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-06-20 06:56:38]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-06-20 06:56:38]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[big-milestone]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[397]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_post_layout]]></wp:meta_key>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What has age got to do with it?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/age-got/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 28 Jun 2014 14:05:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=505</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Mark-Zuckerberg.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-506 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Mark-Zuckerberg.jpg" alt="Mark Zuckerberg" width="314" height="188" /></a>It's a comment often made to 'young entrepreneurs' and one which I am sometimes confused by (maybe I am too young to understand!?)... <strong>But.... "What has age got to do with it?"</strong>

It's unusual for people to make age-related comments to my face, but it's a comment often filtered back to me from those who work for, or simply support the businesses. The normal suspects are competitors (that's to be expected) and skeptics of some degree, but what has age actually got to do with it?

Most people know of Mark Zuckerberg, who together with his college roommates and fellow Harvard University students, launched Facebook from his dormitory room.The group then introduced Facebook onto other campuses nationwide. In 2007, at the <strong>age of 23</strong>, Zuckerberg became a billionaire as a result of Facebook's success. Mark is now a 30 year old Billionaire and is still heavily involved in Facebook to this day...

I am not afraid of telling people that I have a huge amount of support in place from family and friends, not to mention to team who I work with (which was also the case for the Mark Zuckerberg's of this world). Age has absolutely no correlation with how well someone is able to do a job, or indeed run a business. Do you think I do everything myself? of course not... The key is to employ people who are better than you at a particular function and encourage them to succeed - you cannot be good at everything and strategically leading a business is a skill in itself.

Interestingly, one person who commented "I was too young to run a business which deals with peoples lives" is an <span style="text-decoration: underline;">ex-policeman</span>! not a Doctor, not a Paramedic... So is a company like ours, ran by a registered Paramedic (that would be me) and clinically led by a highly experienced air ambulance Doctor not more appropriate than one ran by an <span style="text-decoration: underline;">ex-policeman</span>? - This is down to experience, not Age! There are plenty of 22 year old Paramedics on emergency ambulances up and down the country, clinically responsible for patients... so why can't they run a business?

What I would say is this... If you are young and run a business, employ people who can compliment your enthusiasm and experience, with theirs. Earn respect from them and be part of the team.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Virgin Startup</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/virgin-startup/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Aug 2014 19:20:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=515</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/event-photographer-virgin-start-ups-04.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-516 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/event-photographer-virgin-start-ups-04.jpg" alt="Virgin Start Ups Launch" width="191" height="127" /></a>I am proud to have been accepted as a mentor for Virgin Startup, providing support and guidance for new entrepreneurs. Virgin StartUp is a not-for-profit organisation that helps entrepreneurs with the funding, resources and advice they need to make their business idea a reality.

My role is all about guidance and and helping entrepreneurs to achieve their goals and realise their potential. Help them understand problems, identify solutions and implement their plans. It is about sharing my experiences with them and provide a helping hand when required.
<h2>About Virgin Startup</h2>
Our main focus is to help you get the support you need to turn your great idea in to a successful and sustainable business.

If you are over 18 and a British citizen or legal UK resident who wants to start or expand a new business that’s less than a year old in England then you may be eligible for a start-up loan.

We will help you develop your business plan and your application for funding. Our business advisors will help you with your marketing plans and financial projections.

If you are successful in securing your small business funding we will continue to provide you with support in the form of training, workshops, master classes, peer-to-peer networking and one-to-one mentoring.

Virgin StartUp has developed a mentoring platform to help match you with an experienced business mentor, both in the short and long term.
<h3>You never know - I might just be your mentor....</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>We&#039;re In! Lloyds Bank Enterprise Awards...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/lloyds-bank-enterprise-awards/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 07 Sep 2014 08:45:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=521</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3></h3>
<h3><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Screen-Shot-2014-09-07-at-09.40.07.png"><img class=" wp-image-522 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Screen-Shot-2014-09-07-at-09.40.07.png" alt="Screen Shot 2014-09-07 at 09.40.07" width="331" height="178" /></a>I recently received a very nice phone call from <a href="http://www.lloydsbankenterpriseawards.com/">Lloyds Bank Enterprise Awards</a> with news that we have reached the Semi-Finals!</h3>
<div id="stcpDiv">The panel of experts from Lloyds Bank have shortlisted up to ten entries from <a href="http://www.lloydsbankenterpriseawards.com/how-the-awards-work/#regions-table">each of the five heats</a>. <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> is proud to be one of those shortlisted businesses!</div>
<div></div>
<div>
<div id="stcpDiv">Shortlisted businesses will give a pitch about their company to a <a href="http://www.lloydsbankenterpriseawards.com/judges/">panel of judges</a>, followed by a question and answer session. A Best Start-up, Best Enterprise and Best Digital winner will be selected at each heat to go through to the final. We have been selected into the category of 'Best Enterprise' and on the 16th September I will present our business to the panel of judges.</div>
<div></div>
<div>We are very fortunate as a business to have very stable finances, but the £50,000 investment (should we win overall) would be well invested into cutting edge compliance and CRM software for our recruitment and clinical divisions.</div>
<div></div>
<div>We are very proud to have got this far!</div>
<div></div>
<div>See the shortlist <a href="http://www.lloydsbankenterpriseawards.com/latest/shortlisted.html">here</a></div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Growth and Recruitment: A new chaper of Jigsaw Medical</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/growth-recruitment-new-chaper-jigsaw-medical/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 07 Sep 2014 14:06:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=525</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Those of you who have been following our progress in <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> for a while will know that our Clinical &amp; Training divisions are growing sustainably, but fast!</h2>
[caption id="attachment_526" align="alignright" width="300"]<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/RB.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-526 " style="border: 1px solid black;" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/RB-300x168.jpg" alt="Richard Branson, Kathryn Telford (Jigsaw Paramedic) and Sam Branson" width="300" height="168" /></a> Richard Branson, Kathryn Telford (Jigsaw Paramedic) and Sam Branson[/caption]

If you told me 12 months ago that we would be sponsoring the Virgin STRIVE Challenge, providing a medical team from the o2 Arena to the top of the Mattahorn in Swizerland... and end up with a photograph with Richard Branson, Sam Branson and one of our great Paramedics... I wouldn't be convinced. <strong>This is the amazing thing about being at the helm of Jigsaw Medical!</strong>

Its been a very busy and sometimes challenging journey so far, but one which I would not change for anything. Since the business was born back in February 2012 we have acquired one of our competitors (and the very first company I worked for), increased the headcount significantly and diversified into a comprehensive service, training and recruitment provider - it is the launch of the latter which will see our new chapter in this amazing journey.

Whilst our Training &amp; Clinical divisions have grown to nearly 5 times the size they were last year, we took an un-missable opportunity to diversify once again into leg 3, of our three leg strategy. The provision of <a href="http://recruitment.jigsawmedical.com/">Locum Doctors</a>, Nurses &amp; Paramedics was already what we did, to a degree, however we did not have a formal, staffing-only service provision available to private hospitals, ambulance trusts or NHS Hospitals... enter, the Jigsaw Medical <a href="http://recruitment.jigsawmedical.com">Recruitment Division</a>.

Each of our three divisions can operate completely independently, but importantly - they can also complement each other entirely. We can recruit, train and deploy staff in one provision, in one business - this is extremely unique.

In a market worth over £23 billion, it is exciting to expand into recruitment whilst maintaining our patient centred approach. We have recruited an amazing bunch of people to run our recruitment division and I really look forward to growing all three divisions together and welcoming people to #TeamJigsaw in the months &amp; years to come.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>525</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=730</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=730</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-568" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png" alt="teamjigsaw" width="1600" height="1068" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>It&#039;s all about the brand!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/brand/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Sep 2014 11:11:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=529</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10672308_909261072435284_7317308709202852625_n.jpg"><img class="alignright  wp-image-530" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10672308_909261072435284_7317308709202852625_n.jpg" alt="10672308_909261072435284_7317308709202852625_n" width="315" height="350" /></a>Those of you who know me will also know that my catch phrases go a little something like... "It's all about the brand", or "Get the brand out there"...</h2>
I'm sure people think I am mad, but there is method in my madness! (at least I think there is).

At the heart of a great business is a first class product or service and every business wants to be a customer’s ‘first choice’. Building and managing a brand can play a large part in making this happen and if you want to strengthen and manage the perceptions of your business, then a strong brand is needed. Good branding elevates and differentiates your like-for-like products or services and gives your customers reason to choose you over your competitors.

<strong>But I'm a small business, why should I bother?</strong>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>The most important reason is that it can help increase your sales. This means that when you need to increase your prices (because you are a small company, and there are only so many hours in the day) then your target audience will be accepting of your price increase. Think about it like this - if your company is built upon a solid brand base, you can build up to the next stage successfully without losing the trust of your customers.</li>
	<li>Branding also encourages confidence and trust in your product/service - If you do experience a one-off issue with a product or service, your customers would be more likely to understand, if your brand ethos proves that you’ll do what it takes to resolve the problem.</li>
	<li>Branding also develops the uniqueness of your product.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Trademarks?</strong>

Once your brand has been born and your clients, staff and stakeholders begin to trust your business, you need to protect it. This is a vital part of a business which many people miss out (including the big companies!). Unless you protect your intellectual property then people can just take it from you and damage that hard work you have put into your brand becoming a trusted and powerful force... <a href="http://www.ipo.gov.uk/types/tm.htm">Find out more about trademarks here</a>

<strong><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10620589_529819897118201_8065042768012037413_n.jpg"><img class="wp-image-531 alignleft" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10620589_529819897118201_8065042768012037413_n.jpg" alt="10620589_529819897118201_8065042768012037413_n" width="296" height="222" /></a></strong><strong>Getting the brand out there</strong>

It still amazes me how many companies operate vans with absolutely no branding on at all - that's a big area of virtually free advertising not being utilised. At <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> we take our brand under our wing; our ambulances, response cars, support vehicles and training vans are all heavily branded. It doesn't stop there, with a powerful social presence and more merchandise than you can shake a stick at. Mugs, coasters, pens and mouse-mats - you name it, we have our logo on it!

Many businesses do not believe in promotional items, however I really do think that if its something people will use and it has your brand and contact details on it - surely it can't be a bad idea. You would be amazed how many hospital staff rooms are filled with our bright yellow mugs and matching mouse-mat and coasters!
<h2><span style="color: #ff0000;"><strong>But Remember!</strong></span></h2>
<p id="stcpDiv"><span style="color: #ff0000;"><strong>Branding goes way beyond just a logo or a few mugs... When you think about your brand, you really want to think about your entire customer experience…everything from your logo, your website, your social media experiences, the way you answer the phone, to the way your customers experience your staff. Once you have a brand, you need to live up to its expectations and protect it from harm.</strong></span></p>

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>529</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-09-08 11:11:42]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-09-08 11:11:42]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[brand]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[Internet]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="jigsaw-medical"><![CDATA[Jigsaw Medical]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[531]]></wp:meta_value>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>"Success in business requires discipline and hard work. But if you’re not frightened by these things, the opportunities are just as great today as they ever were." – <em>David Rockefeller</em></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A Great Place To Work</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/great-place-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Sep 2014 08:04:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=535</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/image.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-536" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/image-e1410335388644-300x225.jpg" alt="image" width="300" height="225" /></a>In my short career outside my own businesses, I have worked in some nice places and some really awful places...</h2>
It's not all about beanbag rooms, granted - but having a business where people enjoy to come to work, enjoy the environment and contribute to the way in which they work and the environment they do it in. A new member of our team recently said to me that they loved coming to work and worryingly, they also said they have rarely experienced that in the past. I personally love coming to work and I am thrilled that the team do too, I think that's what makes us stand out from the crowd.
<h3>The single most important thing in ANY business, is its people!</h3>
It may seem easy to employ people and get them into your team, but you also need to make sure you retain the talent you have managed to acquire and develop. I'm really proud of the expanding team we are building at <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw</a>, but I am also aware that we need to make sure we stay '<strong>a great place to work</strong>'. Now (and as we are growing), we need to keep the team involved in everything we do, whether that be what quotes we have on a new wall, what chairs we have in our board rooms - Jigsaw House is, and needs to continue to be a spectacular and special place to work - one which is unique and difficult to replicate by our competitors.
<h3>Are we 'a great place to work'?</h3>
... I certainly hope so, but one thing I do know is that we come together as a team and plan what to do next to make Jigsaw House and even more amazing place to be.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>535</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-09-10 08:04:28]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-09-10 08:04:28]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[great-place-work]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>It&#039;s not about &#039;emulation&#039; or &#039;following suit&#039;...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/emulation-following-suit/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Sep 2014 16:54:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=539</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_536" align="alignright" width="300"]<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/image-e1410335388644.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-536" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/image-e1410335388644-300x225.jpg" alt="image" width="300" height="225" /></a> As our beanbag room suggests... "it's about being different"![/caption]

<strong>It’s not about ‘emulation’ or ‘following suit’…</strong> Copying an existing business will not work – unless you take the bits they are not doing well and make those same 'bits' better in your business. There is a strong case for not re-inventing the wheel and I totally agree with this, but why mirror an imperfect business model when you can innovate and improve it, making it even better!?

There are thousands of businesses doing the same thing we do in the three divisions we cover in Jigsaw Medical, all over the UK…

<strong>So why are we succeeding?</strong>

We have simply taken what the industry doesn’t do very well, and made it 10 times better. For example in the £23 billion market that is recruitment, there are many small and large players – but as an innovative and positive business - ran by clinicians, we know what the rest do well and what they don’t do well. We listen to our locums and make Jigsaw Medical the place they want to commit to, bend over backwards for and have a lot of fun being a part of.

It's about having the right people, doing the right jobs and empowering them enough so they stand out to other employers, but treating them so they won't want to! Business leaders often forget about the people who help them to succeed, it's the leading cause of attrition in high-performing teams and specifically key team members... Be careful, if you operate like this, not only would nobody want to copy your business, there is often a competitor with the right qualities waiting in the sidelines!

Don’t just copy someone else’s business, take the industry by the reins, and <strong>make it better! </strong>
<h2><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Remember</span>: “it’s about being different”</h2>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Lloyds Enterprise Awards... North Heat</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/lloyds-enterprise-awards-north-heat/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Sep 2014 15:28:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=547</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<header>
<h2>Jigsaw Medical wins the Lloyds Enterprise Awards, Best Enterprise (North!)</h2>
<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10646649_539321952834662_6666074932913259183_n.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-549" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10646649_539321952834662_6666074932913259183_n-225x300.jpg" alt="10646649_539321952834662_6666074932913259183_n" width="225" height="300" /></a>

Out of the three categories open to entrepreneurs currently studying at universities across England and Wales – or who graduated within the past five years and have been trading for more than one year. The Best Enterprise award goes to the business which has been running for over two years and demonstrates innovation, as well as showing real potential to grow over the next five years to become a recognised business within its respective sector… <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> are proud to have won Best Enterprise in the Northern heats! As part of the award, Jigsaw will receive a cash investment of £5,000. One-to-one local business mentoring will also be available to prize winners.

</header>Winning the Best Enterprise in the North is an exceptional achievement for the whole team at Jigsaw Medical, it provides recognition of our ethos as a business and our staggering growth, which is this year set to be over 400% on last years figures. We are determined to make Jigsaw a great place to work and develop the business as a team and we look forward to competing in the National awards in October!

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10628536_539393416160849_8752311288722433342_n.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-548" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/10628536_539393416160849_8752311288722433342_n-300x225.jpg" alt="10628536_539393416160849_8752311288722433342_n" width="300" height="225" /></a>Myself and the team at Jigsaw Medical, along with the winners of the other 4 national heats, will qualify for the national award of Best Enterprise at the Grand Final in Edgbaston on October 15, where they will be judged by an expert business panel including Tim Campbell, former Apprentice winner and founder of the Bright Ideas Trust.

The overall Best Enterprise Award winner will receive £50,000 to invest in their business and will also benefit from an additional 2 hour mentoring session with senior executives from Lloyds Banking Group.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Getting The Right Advice...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/getting-right-advice/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Sep 2014 12:14:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=551</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/solicitors.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-552 alignright" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/solicitors-300x197.jpg" alt="solicitors" width="300" height="197" /></a>In business you are likely to require legal advice from time-to-time... it's a fact of life in a commercial world...</h2>
Getting the right advice, from the right solicitors is key when moving forward and protecting your business. Over the last couple of years, during the (thankfully rare) legal matters we have had to either defend or address - we have obtained a great pool of legal firms in order to protect our brand and commercial interests, we have built solid relationships with them and ensure they are ready to act, should this be required.... it also helps that my girlfriend is in the legal world - but she would probably disagree, and for that reason, we don't engage with her professional services directly (but its a perfect place for quick and comparitive advice)!

I remember the very first 'legal letter' I got at aged just 14. It was regarding my 'next big thing' which, during my naive, younger years - got me into a bit of bother (although it did fizzle out when they realised, at the time, all I had was a laptop and a skateboard). The law firm in question specialises in Intellectual Property Law, the letter was fantastically written and so much so, you can guess who we now use for our IP legal requirements now?!

It's amazing really, the bigger your brand &amp; company gets and the more of a commercial threat it poses to your competitors - the more legal correspondence which is required, not just that - the more you need protect your brand (though trademarks etc - see <a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/brand/" target="_blank">here</a>) the more legal input will be required. Although this is not a scientific calculation, I am sure you can imagine their rationale. I guess the truth is, they should be reading my article on: "<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/concentrate-on-you/">Concentrating on your business, not your competitors</a>"

But seriously, having the right legal advisers not only protects your business, but also ensures your approach to legal matters is professional and above all - accurate. We have previously received some terribly written, infactual and very unprofessional 'high street' Solicitors letters - so you can imagine how that reflects on those concerned on the 'other side of the fence'.

<strong>Some top tips when selecting your business' Solicitors....</strong>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Make sure you are clear and focused about what you are trying to achieve so you don’t waste your time and money.</li>
	<li>Before you make any appointments, talk to three or four different firms – you’ll want information about charges, how they handle the longer term adviser/client relationship if that’s relevant - and anything else that is important to you, such as whether they are willing to come and see you in your own workplace.</li>
	<li>Look at their qualifications – what they are, what they mean; ask how long the firm has been in business, <strong>and what your adviser specialises in</strong>! (having a high-street 'generalist' lawyer dealing, for example, with your employment law matters is simply not good!)</li>
	<li>Do they talk to you in plain English or are they using jargon terms that you don’t understand?</li>
	<li>Solicitors should have a practising certificate, which tells you they are fully qualified and insured, which most display in their offices.  If you have any concerns, you can check with the <a href="http://www.sra.org.uk/home/home.page">Solicitors Regulatory Authority</a>.</li>
	<li><strong>and Finally...</strong><strong> Don't be afraid of spending money on senior Partners and highly-commended Solicitors, at the end of the day - it is your business you are protecting.</strong></li>
</ul>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>551</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-09-18 12:14:17]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-09-18 12:14:17]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[getting-right-advice]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="legal"><![CDATA[Legal]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[552]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_post_layout]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[content-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_sidebar_use]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Default Sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_faturedimage_on_single]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[no]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[slide_template]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How important is the financial stability of your suppliers?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/important-financial-stability-suppliers/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Oct 2014 10:47:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=559</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<h2>Suppliers can seriously affect the quality of your products/services and your ability to deliver on your promises!</h2>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/creditscore.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-560" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/creditscore.png" alt="creditscore" width="1055" height="350" /></a><em>This check was done just now, comparing our credit check (on the right), with one of our competitors (left) – obviously we won't tell you which stone you would find them under! - <strong>but the difference is clear!</strong>
</em></p>
If a supplier lets you down, you let your customers down (or in our business, your patients could be at risk). This can damage your business' or NHS Trusts reputation and cause clinical or operational problems. Choosing a supplier without seeing their business report could cost you, or worse, your patients.

Getting a business report to check suppliers helps establish their stability and their ability to provide a quality service, in both the medium and long term. Choosing a reliable, financially stable supplier means that you can be confident you can always fulfil commitments to your customers.
<h4>A supplier check can help you choose the right people to work with</h4>
Business Check from Experian allows you to take an inside look at your current or potential suppliers – that’s what we use!
<strong>A business report lets you check suppliers by seeing information on:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>The stability of suppliers by seeing their credit score</li>
	<li>The future reliability of suppliers with alerts on any changes in their status</li>
</ul>
<h3><strong>With accurate information from a supplier check profile, you can make the right choices for your patients, Trust or business!</strong></h3>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>559</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-10-09 10:47:27]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-10-09 10:47:27]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[important-financial-stability-suppliers]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[564]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Journey So Far - A Moment Of Reflection &amp; Teamwork!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/journey-far-moment-reflection-teamwork/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Oct 2014 16:43:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=567</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Screen-Shot-2014-10-17-at-17.06.54.png"><img class="alignright  wp-image-569" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Screen-Shot-2014-10-17-at-17.06.54-300x214.png" alt="Screen Shot 2014-10-17 at 17.06.54" width="300" height="214" /></a>Following our success in winning the Northern heats of the Lloyds Bank Enterprise Awards we were invited to the Grand Final...</h2>
Although Jigsaw Medical didn't bag the 'grand final prize', settling with the 'Best Enterprise - North' award is something I am immensely proud of the team for and whilst sat with some very inspirational people (which I will come to later), I had time to reflect on where we have been and where we have come...

It seems like only a matter of weeks ago that I was sat with my parents deciding on what to call, what would become '<a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a>' and persuading them that the 'pocket money' I would earn from, at the time, doing event first aid cover, would outweigh the costs of a vehicle, the numerous insurances etc. But as business owners themselves, they fully supported me and helped me get in contact with insurance companies and even (with a slight bending of the ear), let me use one of their company vans! - I must have forgotten to tell them at the time, but I planned on converting into an Ambulance response car - much to their delight on its return from the conversion company! (but that's history... I hope).

Whilst I was sat amongst senior executives from Lloyds Bank, CEO's of multi-national companies and inspiring business leaders, I had time to reflect on what Jigsaw Medical has 'grown up to be'. I was sat there with my Parents and Sammie (my girlfriend) and numerous people wanted to hear all about the business, which was fine, because I can talk about it all day!!

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png"><img class="wp-image-568 alignleft" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png" alt="teamjigsaw" width="357" height="238" /></a>Sat on the 'Jigsaw Medical table' was <a href="http://www.tonyrobinsonobe.co.uk/">Tony Robbinson OBE</a>, not only was he such a gent and such an inspiring chap, it was an absolute pleasure to be in his company, hear his stories and experiences. <a href="http://www.tim-campbell.co.uk/">Tim Campbell MBE</a> was also judging the final and it was amazing to hear his story and experience his frankly awesome speech! - I was humbled to be amongst some inspirational and amazing people, something I had not experienced before - with the 'spotlight' being on us.

But it was this that made me realise something.... the journey I had embarked upon in February 2012 had brought me to that position, sat on that table, surrounded by 'Jigsaw Medical' branding, a 6-foot high picture of my face (which they must have forgotten to tell me about!). Not to mention being in the company of two legends such as Tony, Tim and the amazing judges. But it's not that which really made me reflect on where we are today. Although I had the pleasure of being there and pitching the company to these influential and powerful people, <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>It is not me</strong></span> who has simply landed there by mistake (or at least I hope not) and certainly not single-handedly, its the teamwork and the amazing people we have on-board the Jigsaw journey that has got us there, it just happens to be me who founded the business and has the pleasure to lead the team. I knew that already, but when you reflect on how far the team has come, it's pretty amazing!! We call these people #TeamJigsaw and it includes everyone, our Locum Doctors and Nurses, event Paramedics, sales team, office team, recruitment team, first aiders and the team in FM - absolutely <strong>everyone</strong> involved in the business as a whole. It is these people who determine its success, not me.

With all of the growth and concentration in the entire team, I wouldn't say "I didn't know how far we have come", but I certainly didn't appreciate our collective success, as an entire team and when I compare it to where we were just 12 months ago, with 300% growth a successful acquisition and a rapidly growing team!
<h3>Tim, Tony and the whole experience of the Enterprise Awards made me reflect and really put our achievements so far into perspective, so I suppose all that would be left to say is....</h3>
<h2><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em>Thank You</em> to the awesome #TeamJigsaw!</span> - Here's to the next part of the journey....</h2>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>567</wp:post_id>
