	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Business Dress Code... Suit or Jeans?...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/business-dress-code-suit-jeans/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Nov 2014 17:54:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=582</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>I recently had an interesting debate with some of my family about what I should wear to meetings...</h2>
<strong>My general rule has always been Suits &amp; Ties are for Weddings, Funerals and Court... those in <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> and my family know this well and when I occasionally do put a suit on, they get very concerned indeed!</strong>

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/0210-MARK-ZUCKERBERG-sized.jpg_full_600.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-583" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/0210-MARK-ZUCKERBERG-sized.jpg_full_600-161x300.jpg" alt="0210-MARK-ZUCKERBERG-sized.jpg_full_600" width="161" height="300" /></a>I personally think there are no rules about suits, ties and any of the other 60's contraptions that people think constitute 'business wear'. I honestly think that gone are the days of Directors and business people wearing suits. My rule has always been that people dress smartly but more importantly, comfortably... maybe one day we will do some experiment to prove my theory that comfortable people work more efficiently, happily and enjoy going to work more - but to me, its common sense.

Don't get me wrong, I believe in people being smart, but I would never insist on someone wearing a suit... and certainly not a tie! (I do share <a href="http://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/why-it%E2%80%99s-time-to-say-bye-to-the-tie">Mr Branson's view on ties</a>!). Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, the late Steve Jobs and Richard Branson (to name a few) do not wear traditional suits... I really <span style="text-decoration: underline;">don't</span> believe there is science in this next statement, but look how creative, forward thinking and successful these three people are and have been! I recently met Richard Reed (the Founder of Innocent Drinks), again he was in a t-shirt a jeans - another hugely creative and successful guy... maybe that's because they worked in comfort?

If I existed in business 25 years ago (or was even born), I am sure my view may be different - but then again as was the world, technology and the existence of small businesses to the extent they are today. To some extent I think people wear what they have been brought up to wear.

I don't wear a suit (if I can help it), that's not me being arrogant, its me being comfortable so I can perform my best. Those who disagree with my dress code often say they don't feel at work without a suit on, in which case they may well feel more comfortable in a suit! (but I would urge them to try the jeans, shirt and suit jacket attire!)
<h4>Some will agree, some will disagree, but as long as people are smart, comfortable and happy - that sounds good to me!</h4>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>582</wp:post_id>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>An office in Sydney... now I didn&#039;t expect to be saying that just 2 years into the journey!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/office-sydney-now-didnt-expect-saying-just-2-years-journey/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 16 Nov 2014 13:20:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=592</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>I must say, I didn't think I would be writing about an office in Australia for some years yet, but it is testament to the team at <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> that we have managed to make this bold move so soon in our journey..<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/sydney_harbour.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-593" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/sydney_harbour-300x199.jpg" alt="sydney_harbour" width="300" height="199" /></a></h3>
Granted, we are not the first recruitment agency, training company or clinical provider who has made such a move. However, we will be the only UK based agency dealing with Paramedics internationally, on this scale. Our aim is to use this new brand (Jigsaw Medical Global) and our presence in Australia to drive recruitment in and out of the UK, with offshore and onshore opportunities already available globally. It has been an amazing journey, especially given that I only actual finished university and became a full-time member of the team, just 16 months ago! The markets in all three divisions of our business are saturated, but I have learn't over this short space of time, that it really doesn't matter - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">providing what you are doing is different</span> (those of you who have been to Jigsaw House will have seen quotes to this effect all over the walls!).

The whole team at Jigsaw Medical are so pleased to have made this positive and forward thinking move, we are uniquely placed to recruit, train and deploy heath-care staff across our three divisions; something that to our knowledge, has never been done before. It is an absolute credit to our team that we have got to this point so quickly and we are really looking forward to developing our Global team at our Sydney office and beyond…

&nbsp;

To find out more about Jigsaw Medical Global, visit our dedicated website <a href="http://www.jigsawmedicalglobal.com">www.jigsawmedicalglobal.com</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Business Is All About People...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/business-people/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 16 Nov 2014 13:25:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=595</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>595</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2014-11-16 13:25:09]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2014-11-16 13:25:09]]></wp:post_date_gmt>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>2014... From the Tour de France, to the Matterhorn, to Australia - What a year it&#039;s been!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/2014-tour-de-france-matterhorn-australia-year/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 22 Dec 2014 17:08:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=600</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>The first time I had the chance to really stop and think about where we have come in 2014 was when designing the front cover of our annual review...</h2>
<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Screen-Shot-2014-12-22-at-16.18.16.png"><img class="alignright wp-image-601 size-medium" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Screen-Shot-2014-12-22-at-16.18.16-218x300.png" alt="Screen Shot 2014-12-22 at 16.18.16" width="218" height="300" /></a>I found myself looking through the Jigsaw Medical Facebook pictures to design an eye catching cover for our 2014 Annual Report, the first of its kind since the beginnings of Jigsaw Medical. With pictures of our team with <a href="http://www.virgin.com/richard-branson">Richard Branson</a> and Sam Branson at the <a href="https://www.strivechallenge.com/">Virgin STRIVE Challenge</a>, images from the 'Tour de France' and of our ambulances queuing up outside A&amp;E departments on 999 work with various trusts.

It was at this point that I was able to stop and reflect, I wouldn't say I forgot about everything we have done this year, but rather that we were too busy on the very fast road of growth to do so. (something I'm sure I will set as a goal for 2015, so I do more of it!). Nonetheless this urged me to send an email to the team across our three offices to thank them for their efforts in 2014 and highlight some of the amazing things that we, together, have achieved. I would like to think I give thanks to the team very regularly, but the realisation of what we have achieved holistically is something easily forgotten in this fast-pace environment we have created.

I remember just 12 months ago, sitting with my family at the Blackhouse Grill in Chester, discussing my (at the time) rather ambitious vision for Jigsaw Medical. I distinctly remember saying <em>"I would love to be sat here in a few years seeing a Jigsaw Medical ambulance driving past the window, on a 999 call"</em>. Strangely, last Friday I was sat in this same restaurant with some of the team from Jigsaw Medical, celebrating our achievements in 2014. Just 12 months on, that goal became a reality as 'JA603', one of our Emergency Ambulances drove past whilst on contract with the local NHS Ambulance Service... for me that was a huge moment and something which will stick with me forever, there was a moment of madness in the restaurant as the team saw one of our own driving past! It may seem a bit cheesy, but there is absolutely nothing like the feeling of hitting these goals, especially when you least expect it!
<h4>So... Jigsaw Medical in 2014 - A Review...</h4>
<a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2014-@-Jigsaw.jpg"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-1151" src="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2014-@-Jigsaw.jpg" alt="Processed with Moldiv" width="259" height="260" /></a><strong>A <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/jigsaw-medical-2014-review/">recent blog entry from Neil Coleman</a>, our social media &amp; PR guru summarised things nicely! I have taken some key bits from his post...</strong>

What a year it’s been at Jigsaw Medical. Unrivalled growth, exciting event coverage, overseas expansion, laughs, tears and everything that comes along with being part of one of the UK’s leading and most innovative medical recruitment, clinical and training companies. 2014 saw the establishment of a new <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/recruitment/">recruitment division</a> that offers a formal, staffing-only service provision available to private hospitals, ambulance trusts and NHS hospitals.

It has also been a particularly exciting year for our <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/home.html">clinical division</a>, as Jigsaw provided medical cover not only for traditional ambulance settings but also for:
<ul>
	<li>Virgin STRIVE challenge – providing a medical team for 10 people who ran, rowed, cycled, hiked and climbed from the O2 arena in London to the peak of the Matterhorn in Switzerland.</li>
	<li>Tour de France Grand Départ – supporting the first aid providers, NHS ambulance services and event medical management company with the provision of 227 paramedics, nurses and doctors throughout the 2 days.</li>
	<li>The Big Reunion, UK’s Biggest Winter Music Festival – providing comprehensive medical services and treatment for all festival goers.</li>
	<li>Various NHS 999 Contracts - supporting NHS trusts with emergency 999 calls, accross the UK.</li>
</ul>
<a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Jigsaw-Medical-Global-Glow-Bg.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-968" src="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Jigsaw-Medical-Global-Glow-Bg.png" alt="Jigsaw-Medical-Global-Glow-Bg" width="277" height="72" /></a>2014 also saw the creation of <a href="http://www.jigsawmedicalglobal.com/">Jigsaw Medical Global</a>. This expansion has seen the Jigsaw Medical brand go to Sydney, Australia to become the only UK based agency to deal with paramedics internationally on this scale. The aim is to use this opportunity to drive recruitment in and out of the UK, with offshore and onshore opportunities already available to UK based candidates and global candidates.

<strong>All of the above has contributed to a 350% growth in comparison to where we were in 2013 so we’d like to say a massive thank you and congratulations to everyone at #TeamJigsaw for a fantastic 2014.</strong>
<h3>2014 In Summary</h3>
I think it is safe to say that we as a team are as shocked as everyone else to see where we have come, although it has taken a considerable amount of effort from the entire team to get it right. We needed to ensure we kept delivering the same, clinically focused service to our clients and patients is something we made a priority at every step. To be honest, I personally feel that having the right people on-board, improving our service delivery and clinical focus has resulted in much of this staggering growth.

Our growth has also seen a 300% increase in the size of our full-time office &amp; training team, with over 2,000 candidates joining #TeamJigsaw over the last few months. We took some bold steps for a young company in 2014, but we have done it with the right support and the right people on board, from our appointment of our Finance Director, to ensure the growth is financially sustainable and our Medical Director, to ensure it is clinically appropriate. Not to mention those with a wealth of experience to drive us forward strategically, including <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/jms-appoints-laurie-percival-as-non-executive-director/">Laurie Percival</a> who came to us from her position as CEO of a £500 million recruitment brand.

I am convinced the single reason for our growth and success in 2014 is <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/our-people.html">our people</a>, who we like to call #TeamJigsaw! - <strong>So thank you to everyone who has helped make this year so successful!</strong>
<h3>What to Expect in 2015?</h3>
Needless to say, we have a plan. However, our plan for this year has been exceeded more than three times over - so who knows what to expect. However, what I will say is that it will see more amazing people join #TeamJigsaw and we hope to increase revenue and profits by some 500%, largely down to our sustained growth &amp; innovation across the three divisions within the business. We will have more shifts for locum workers, more courses in our training division, lots more clinical service provision to events, private &amp; NHS clients, and international opportunities for UK Paramedics - to name a few.

In a nutshell we want to continue on from 2014 with a vision to 'revamping' the UK medical recruitment market, continuing to innovate and develop in our Clinical &amp; Training divisions. I truly believe we have a unique model with the very best team, something which I can see being very powerful and pioneering in 2015, and beyond.
<h3>I will leave you with this thought...</h3>
I love quotes and those of you who have visited us at Jigsaw House will know that (they are all over the walls). The most recent of which is a selection for my new office, for example one from Walt Disney - "If you can dream it, you can do it"....

<strong>...However more prudent to this blog post, another reads....</strong>
<h2 style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/4d3c1c5bf36fa.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-605" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/4d3c1c5bf36fa.jpg" alt="4d3c1c5bf36fa" width="600" height="445" /></a>Merry Christmas &amp; Happy New Year... Here's to 2015!</h2>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How Dreamers Can Become Doers...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/dreamers-can-become-doers/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Dec 2014 17:50:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=612</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/141112_goals.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-613" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/141112_goals.jpg" alt="141112_goals" width="600" height="400" /></a></h3>
<h3>One of the quotes in my office is from Walt Disney and it reads: "If you can dream it, you can do it"... but how do dreamers become doers?...</h3>
Granted, it is true that the 'doing' part of this statement is the harder part of the two, but I strongly believe that the above quote is very true. Most of the time, it is the fear of failure or 'not knowing where to start' which stops entrepreneurs from 'doing' rather than 'dreaming'!
<h3>Some top tips which might just help you to turn your dreams into reality!</h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Have goals! - </strong>You should have goals, whether they are just a goal for Monday, a goal for the month or a goal further ahead… You need them to be the first thing you do on your quest to develop your dream into reality! Don’t forget – if your goal involves your team (which I’m sure it will), you need to share it with them, so they can also focus on helping you reach it!</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Surround yourself with doers, not dreamers -</strong>  I think it is safe to say everyone has dreams, but make sure you are surrounding yourself with positive, like-minded people - particularly if they themselves have turned some of their dreams into reality, they will no doubt have some pointers for you from their journey.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Nothing is impossible! - </strong>If you think your goal is out of reach, think again. Whilst I wouldn't encourage anyone to try and beat Richard Branson into space tourism with a start-up business, you should work towards milestones to ultimately get you to the main goal. Be realistic, but don't make it easily achievable - that's boring!<strong>
</strong></li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Be better -</strong> Take some time to sit down &amp; figure out how your biggest competitor is promoting their brand &amp; plan something smarter &amp; more creative for yours... Don't re-invent the wheel without being creative!</li>
</ul>
<h3>Will it work!?</h3>
... If everyone knew the answer to that question, we would all be very successful in everything we wanted to do... But I do believe, nothing is impossible if you have the right people and the right formula.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="startup"><![CDATA[startup]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Turning to Twitter for Customer Service...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/turning-twitter-customer-service/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 30 Dec 2014 10:27:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=617</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Customer-Service-on-Twitter-sorry.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-618" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Customer-Service-on-Twitter-sorry.png" alt="Customer-Service-on-Twitter-sorry" width="540" height="301" /></a></h3>
<h3>Many businesses are turning to Twitter and other social media platforms for their customer service, are you Tweeting back?</h3>
I'm sure that I'm not the only person who turns to Twitter, Facebook or finding the CEO on Linkedin when I have a query or problem? People often want instant responses to their customer service queries, not emails which often take 24hrs to respond to! I think it's safe to say that social media has a massive impact on how a company is perceived to the public, especially the response time from Tweets, whether that's a rare complaint, question or sales enquiry. So much so, many businesses (including Jigsaw Medical) employ dedicated people in their teams to manage their social media requirements (our is <a href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/blog/jigsaw-medical-appoints-social-media-pr-intern/">Neil Coleman</a>, who looks more like Olly Murs!).

I recently had a positive experience of social media based customer support with <a href="http://www.londonmidland.com/">London Midland Trains </a>and whilst they couldn't rectify the issue, the response from them via Twitter was both speedy and appropriate. Other great examples comes from some of our suppliers, such as <a href="http://www.ukfast.co.uk">UKFast</a> and our clients, including the many <a href="http://www.virgin.com">Virgin</a> brands you see around the world - they all seem to have exceptional Twitter interaction &amp; support!
<h3><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/social-channles-image-01.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-621" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/social-channles-image-01-300x184.jpg" alt="social-channles-image-01" width="300" height="184" /></a>Why should your business use Social Media?...</h3>
There still seems to be a clear split between businesses and indeed the people within them as to their view on how businesses should use social media. Many see employing people to manage social media as a strange move - but I can assure you it's not! Here are some top reasons why you should be using social media:

<strong>Customer Service -</strong> This is the  main reason why you should use social media for your business. You will be able to connect with your customers because they themselves are using it. Specifically Twitter has become a daily routine for many consumers and businesses alike, if you have an unsatisfied customer you are likely to hear from them on twitter (whether or not your company has a presence!). Surely it's better to manage their feedback publicly on Twitter, rather than not know about it at all!?

<strong>Branding -</strong> You don’t have to be a big brand like Google or Starbucks to brand yourself on social media channels. For many, the use of Twitter, Linkedin and Facebook is an opportunity to re-enforce the brand and what better for a huge advertising platform than this! Many businesses (including Jigsaw Medical, which is why you are reading this) also have their Directors or leaders on Twitter and other social platforms.

<strong>News - </strong>Social media is also a great platform to share your news with your followers and keep them updated with the latest 'happenings' in your organisation.

<strong>"It's gone viral!"</strong> - If you have succeeded gaining some popularity with your social media accounts you will know how viral they can be. This will be part of your marketing strategies that you can use in the future. Hey, it worked for Justin Beiber! - just think of social media as a free advertising platform.

<strong>Willingness to act</strong> - I personally think this is the single most important reason your business should use Social Media. If you allow yourself to be potentially exposed on social media, with the correct management this can be seen extremely positively by your clients. This shows willingness and transparency, reassuring your customers that you are willing to act on peoples concerns or feedback.

<strong>Everyone's doing it!</strong> - The guy who runs the local sweet shop down the road. The landscape architect. The shoe shop owner. And lots of big companies, such as Dell, HP, 02 and Microsoft. Having your business on Twitter is seen as a must.
<h3>The golden rules...<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/golden-rules.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-622" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/golden-rules.png" alt="golden-rules" width="700" height="200" /></a></h3>
<strong>1. If your going to do it, do it properly! </strong>- Don't fall into the trap of thinking social media is a great idea for your business, setting up your Facebook page, Twitter account and Linkedin company page - then leaving it for 12-months post-less! Unmanaged social media accounts are bad news and when your latest customer searches your company name on social media channels and sees the inactivity - it looks worse than not being on social media at all! No matter how small your business, as a minimum you should aim to do at least one tweet, Facebook and LinkedIn post, each week. If you don't have time to do this, there are lots of web and marketing company's who can manage this on you behalf for little cost, but remember, it's always better coming from you.

<strong>2. Whilst your at it, get the boss on too</strong> - Whether your organisation is large or small, professional accounts for the leaders, founders and Directors can also work in your company's favor. I am on Twitter, Facebook and Linkedin and I often get queries direct to my account, rather than the companies. This again shows <span class="st">transparency</span> and allows people to really become involved and get a complete view of the organisation holistically. Whilst this isn't for everyone, I really enjoy the feedback from our clients and team on social media and it's something which allows me to be easily accessible if someone does have an issue.

<strong>3. Think before you Tweet </strong>- Having been here myself on a number of occasions it can often be too easy to respond in a confrontational way if someone (such as a competitor) is being less than polite about your business on social media. This is one of the reasons why Neil manages Jigsaw Medical's social media, he is a professional and ensures our responses as a company are both appropriate, yet professional. My advice is to take 10 minutes before replying and I can assure you the words you chose in your response will be very different. Just remember, once its on social media, its on for life - whether you delete it or not, the damage is often done.

<strong>4. Set goals</strong> - Yes, I'm always squeezing this one in... but goals can apply to anything. For example, your goal could be to gain 500 followers on Twitter in the first six months, so set this and monitor it. The great thing about social media is that you can share these goals with your audience. One great example of this was when I recently provided an opportunity for one of my followers on Twitter to win a famous Jigsaw Medical bobble hat! This worked really well and I hit the target of reaching 40,000 followers that day. Be creative and engage your followers as much as you can.

<strong>5. It's not just about numbers - </strong>Don't get yourself bogged down with how many followers you do or don't have, concentrate on those you do have, engage with them and make them feel part of your journey. Don’t try to follow 10,000 people straight away. You’ll just come across as a spammer. There is no value in a multitude of followers or 'likes' if they don’t really care about what you have to say. It’s about conversations, relationships and engagement, not the masses. Build your “network” gradually and consistently. Be selective, be targeted, and be clear on what your objectives are.
<h3>Whats next?</h3>
If you haven't already, get your social media accounts setup and start engaging with your customers!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_post_layout]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[content-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_sidebar_use]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Default Sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Setting Goals for 2015...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/setting-goals-2015/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Jan 2015 08:58:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=629</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/index.jpg"><img class="alignright wp-image-630 size-full" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/index.jpg" alt="index" width="224" height="192" /></a>January is often the month where people kick off the plan for the year ahead and set their goals on track...</h2>
Firstly, you should remember that a business may at first be the vision of just one person, but soon becomes the vision of the whole team of people you employ or involve in your business. <strong>So rule number one; let your team come up with the goals as well as you! </strong>If your business culture is similar to Jigsaw's the business is as much your teams as it is yours.

I am a keen believer in goals and lining up a target, this goes for business and personal life. My business goals come in all shapes and sizes and focus on different aspects of my businesses. At the beginning of the year it is important to lay some foundation goals - where do you want to get to that year?, where do your team what to get to? and importantly make them measurable, objective and realistic (although #TeamJigsaw would tell you mine are often very ambitious!).
<h2>Involve your team</h2>
I know I am repeating myself here. But don’t forget, your goals with invariably involve your team, so you need to share it with them and involve them in the goal setting process, so they can also focus on helping you reach it! Don’t just keep it to yourself!
<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10868092_989236447771079_4293696508673558744_n.jpg"><img class="alignright wp-image-631 size-medium" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10868092_989236447771079_4293696508673558744_n-300x300.jpg" alt="10868092_989236447771079_4293696508673558744_n" width="300" height="300" /></a>Sit back before you set...</h2>
I recently went away skiing at the beginning of January and something I have picked up from <a href="http://www.lawrencejones.eu">Lawrence Jones MBE</a> is that taking time out to look at the bigger picture is vital (something it took me a while to get the hang of). You would be amazed what spending time on the mountains with your family can spark in your goal setting and even thought process - try it!

Today I have the first board meeting of the year and in the 'upside down management' structure we have in Jigsaw Medical - the goals have already been set, the team have come together and made a plan for 2015, so lets hope its an awesome one.
<h2>Some personal goals...</h2>
As well as the goals for the business (which you should share), I think its also important to have some personal goals to keep yourself motivated. They can be kept to yourself or shared with your friends, family or colleagues... Here are a couple of mine:
<ul>
	<li>To visit <a href="http://www.virginlimitededition.com/en/necker-island">Necker Island</a> at some point in 2015</li>
	<li>To make in profit, what we generated in revenue in 2014 (this is a personal one as its one of those 'ambitious ones' I spoke of. However, we did do this in 2014, so nothing is impossible!)</li>
	<li>To further support start-up businesses, just like I was in February 2012</li>
</ul>
<h2>... so what are your goals for 2015?</h2>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>629</wp:post_id>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A Dedicated Team...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/dedicated-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Feb 2015 12:18:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=636</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/13234_950531914974866_3435897560069943772_n.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-638" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/13234_950531914974866_3435897560069943772_n-300x225.jpg" alt="13234_950531914974866_3435897560069943772_n" width="300" height="225" /></a>"The price of success is hard work, dedication to the job at hand, and the determination that whether we win or lose, we have applied the best of ourselves to the task at hand." - Vince Lombardi</h2>
This morning reminded me of what such a dedicated team can achieve. I woke up to a text message from our Operations Manager (Jon Gooding), which outlined where he had spent the night... (this might sound somewhat ominous, but I can assure you it's not!) He actually spent until 02:45 this morning at our head office, solving a time-critical mechanical issue with one of our vehicles which resulted in it being taken to a 24hr Mercedes garage to be fixed, keeping our operations unaffected.
<h3><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Y2TN11.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-639" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Y2TN11-199x300.jpg" alt="Y2TN11" width="199" height="300" /></a>A 9 to 5 Job...</h3>
Jon, like many of our head office and training team, works 9-5 with an additional on-call rota. He didn't have to come in last night and rectify this issue - but he did, which meant we had a happy client.

The same can also be said for our recruitment team, who take calls at midnight from staff in hospitals and on shifts UK Wide. It can also be said for our training team who offer to deliver courses in the evenings or the weekends to fit in with our clients requirements. Our finance team, who stay until 8pm to make sure our payroll is ran and #TeamJigsaw get paid on-time; or our sales team, who books an event on a Friday night, for the following day to ensure their event is able to continue. Not least our 24/7 ambulance crews who work over their allotted shift time to ensure a critically ill baby can be quickly transferred to receive the care they desperately need, or our Doctors, Nurses &amp; Paramedics who go that extra mile to get the job done right.

All of this results in us giving our clients what they want and our patients what they need, providing that second-to-none service we aim to achieve. Many of our clients won't see what happens behind the scenes at #TeamJigsaw, but I can assure you this group of amazing people never cease to amaze me.

We don't aim to 'overwork' our team, but when working for a fast-growing business such as Jigsaw Medical, having people who go that extra mile really makes us stand out from the crowd!
<h3>It's about the people</h3>
When people ask me the secret to the success of Jigsaw Medical so far, I respond unequivocally with "it's the team, not me". This is often responded to with a laugh - perhaps they expected me to say something else?

I think it's safe to say, the above proves that its the people who make the difference.
<h3>Thank you #TeamJigsaw - here's to a successful 2015</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>New additions and vacancies at #TeamJigsaw...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/new-additions-and-vacancies-at-teamjigsaw/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Mar 2015 11:46:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=709</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>After unprecedented growth of 382% and an increase in profits of 213% in 2014, #TeamJigsaw is happy to announce the appointment of a new PR &amp; Social Media Manager and a new Recruitment Consultant for our Nurses department.</h3>
Neil Coleman and Matt Jones are appointed to the respective posts of PR and Social Media Manager, and Recruitment Consultant. Neil was looking for a career change and joins us after completing a 3 month internship, having previously had more than seven years in customer service and account management. Matt joins #TeamJigsaw's nurse recruitment division after 14 years’ in sales and customer service.

As well as these new additions we are looking to add to the team, and are currently recruiting candidates for two new roles; a <a title="Recruitment Compliance Administrator Job Description" href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/connect/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Compliance-Administrator.pdf" target="_blank">Recruitment Compliance Administrator</a> and an <a title="Accounts/Payroll Administrator Job Description" href="http://www.jigsawmedical.com/connect/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Accounts-Payroll-Administrator.pdf" target="_blank">Accounts/Payroll Administrator</a>.

The role of Recruitment Compliance Administrator would suit some who ideally has experience within the medical or recruitment industry, is able to work flexibly but office-based, has exceptional organisational skills and has interest in planning their own time effectively. They will be working with healthcare professionals to ensure their documentation is stored correctly onto an in-house database.

Additionally, the Accounts/Payroll Administrator role would suit someone who ideally has experience of operating the payroll and raising invoices within the medical or recruitment industry and is an excellent communicator with good organisational skills.

I'm a firm believe that people are at the heart of our success. We are proud of our creative and positive working environment, and strive to make sure our team enjoy coming to work.

Jigsaw was built on foundations of transparent and collaborative working from board level to each area of our business.

If candidates would like to apply for either of the roles or find out more, they can contact our team on <a class="DetectedNumber" title="01829 732615" href="dial:01829732615">01829 732615</a> or email <a href="mailto:recruitment@jigsawmedical.com">recruitment@jigsawmedical.com</a>.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-568" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/teamjigsaw.png" alt="teamjigsaw" width="900" height="601" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>CEO Selfie for Comic Relief</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/ceo-selfie-for-comic-relief/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Mar 2015 12:43:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=718</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<h1 class="quoteText">“No one has ever become poor by giving.” – Anne Frank.</h1>
In order to help celebrate Comic Relief day this year I've decided to take part in the #CEOSelfie campaign.

The aim of the campaign is for CEOs around the country to help change the face of their business by posting a selfie on the CEO Selfie website (www.ceoselfie.co.uk) and making a donation to Comic Relief.

As well as directly raising money for the Comic Relief charity it will also help raise awareness of the tireless work that they do, not only on leading up to #RedNoseDay but throughout the year to help tackle poverty and social inequality in the UK and around the world.

Since the charity was formed in 1985 it has raised £950 million the help the above causes, with over 40% of that being spent directly on issues here in the UK.

Charity is an issue close to my heart and it always important to give something back. So much so that here at #TeamJigsaw we have set up our own charitable cause called <a title="Jigsaw Foundation" href="Since%20the launch of Jigsaw Medical, Chris has always believed in giving back and supporting charitable causes. Over the years Jigsaw and Chris personally have donated, supported and been involved in countless charitable activities across the country. The Jigsaw Foundation was set up to formalise our charitable aim and allow our team to decide on which charities the company wishes to support each year. We do this a number of ways, including by pledging to donate at least 1% of profits to charity." target="_blank">Jigsaw Foundation</a>, which was set up to formalise our charitable aim and allow our team to decide on which charities the company wishes to support each year. We do this a number of ways, including by pledging to donate at least 1% of profits to charity.

So if there are any other CEOs out there who haven't already done so. Get your smartphone, take a #CEOSelfie and upload it to the website...and don't forget to donate!!

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Photo-13-03-2015-09-23-23.jpg"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-720" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Photo-13-03-2015-09-23-23.jpg" alt="Chris_Percival_CEOSelfie" width="900" height="1200" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

</div>
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What makes a good mentor?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/what-make-a-good-mentor/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Apr 2015 10:27:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=736</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="page" title="Page 1">
<div class="section">
<div class="layoutArea">
<div class="column">
<div>
<h3>After coming out of a meeting with one of my mentees last week it got me thinking about what makes a good mentor and what it means to me to be a mentor.</h3>
I was asked to become a Virgin Startup Mentor a couple of years ago and have thoroughly enjoyed every moment of it ever since. I love being able to make a real different to people's lives and their aspirations in business by providing them with support, guidance and encouragement, as well a few helpful tips that I have learnt along the way!

A good mentor relationship can be deeply rewarding for both parties involved as long as it is done properly. So what makes a good mentor?

The first key to becoming a good mentor is being genuinely interested in the person you're mentoring and to also believe in them personally and professionally. You need to make the effort to understand them and their business which will enable you to mentor them in a way that they need.

The relationship works both ways, therefore you must have credibility and have achieved some success in the area you are mentoring in otherwise the mentee will not trust your advice and feedback. I may be (quite) young but I like to think that with the things I have already achieved in business I can be seen as credible when mentoring young(er!) entrepreneurs.

This credibility will help you share your insights and experiences and ensure the mentee will take them aboard. Don't be afraid to share any mistakes or tough times you have had in the past; starting and running a business is never always easy-sailing (if you haven't had any downs yet they're unfortunately to come), however as long as you learn from mistakes and adversity you'll always come out the other side better, more determined and, dare-I-say-it, wiser!

Providing feedback and advice is a key part of being a mentor, but choosing the correct type of feedback and delivering at the right time is the challenging. Giving unwelcome feedback or unnecessary advice can be detrimental to morale and can affect the relationship with your mentee.

Finally, always remember to highlight any achievements that the mentee has made; celebrating their successes will help build their confidence and will make the relationship much stronger.

The most important thing to remember about being a mentor is the fact that every mentee and relationship is different; although the things above can be taken into consideration you have to be flexible and adapt to the person being mentored. Each situation will be different to the next but if done right there’s a lot of enjoyment that can come from watching someone develop and reach their full potential!

We all need mentors, I’m lucky enough to have very experienced and very inspirational mentors – without whom, Jigsaw would not be what it is today.

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why should you start your own business?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/5-reasons-to-start-your-own-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2015 14:45:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=761</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I started out in business at the tender (and slightly naive) age of 14 and have always wanted to run a business and achieve goals. I set about this whilst at University, which in hindsight probably wasnt the most sensible option but we all have to start somewhere, and decided to combine my passion for emergency medicine and creativity by forming Jigsaw Medical. I wouldn’t have it any other way, so I’ve decided to talk through my 5 top reasons for starting your own company…

1) <strong>Make your own decisions.</strong> I’m not one to make decisions without consulting my team, but I love having a direct impact on the culture and future of my company. This leads into my second reason…

2) <strong>Creativity</strong>. Having the ability to create our own opportunities and brand is amazing, our brand at Jigsaw Medical has become very recognisable and I’m very proud of how it has developed and become a sign of quality in the medical industry.

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/JMS-Logo-PNG1.png"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-770" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/JMS-Logo-PNG1.png" alt="JMS Logo (PNG)" width="1002" height="239" /></a>

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Screen-Shot-2015-05-08-at-10.32.52.png"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-767" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Screen-Shot-2015-05-08-at-10.32.52.png" alt="jigsaw-branding" width="1002" height="657" /></a>

3) <strong>Doing what you enjoy</strong>. I work long hours but do it for something I’m passionate about it doesn’t feel like work (most of the time!). I imagine there is nothing worse than dreading going to work everyday and I am lucky enough not have to worry about that.

4) <strong>Picking my own team.</strong> I get to choose exactly who I want to work with. As I stated earlier we will always employ someone if we believe they can do a job for #TeamJigsaw, however I have to feel that they are willing to invest in the ethos of the company. As a result I like to think (and I hope our team would agree) that coming to work at Jigsaw House is enjoyable and not something you dread on a Sunday evening.

5) <strong>Being a mentor</strong>. As Jigsaw has grown and become more successful I was to be a mentor for <a title="Virgin Startup" href="http://www.virginstartup.org/" target="_blank">Virgin Startup</a> helping new entrepreneurs on their journey helping young entrepreneurs on their journey into owning their own business. If done right there’s a lot of enjoyment that can come from watching someone develop and reach their full potential!

6) Ok I said there was 5 but this one is important. <strong>Your reason.</strong> The list above details my reasons. if you’re reading this blog post you probably already have an interest in starting your own business. So, what is your reason? Share on social media and include your reason or comment below.

What are you waiting for?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Event Season Underway!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/event-season-underway/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Jul 2015 09:57:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=787</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The sun is shining and the UK events season is up and running. That means that event organisers all over the UK will be implementing those plans to execute an amazing event.

With Jigsaw Medical's recent appointment of Richard McManus as 'Head of Events', our capability and deliverabity has just got massive.

As you will always hear me say - "it's about the right people, in the right places" and Richard is no different, he joins #TeamJigsaw following a wide and varied career history. After serving in the Royal Navy for 7 years, he trained as an Aircraft Firefighter and medic serving in various destinations all over the world. Through this Richard become interested in pre-hospital medicine and on leaving the Navy joined the Yorkshire Ambulance Service and then North West Ambulance Service to complete his training.

As a Paramedic has been lucky enough to work on some of the UK's largest music events, sporting events and through this has developed a passion for event planning and medical management where he has been responsible for some of the UK's biggest events, such as V Festival. Richard particularly worked very closely with Jigsaw Medical last year as the primary link between the Tour de France and Jigsaw Medical teams and via this partnership a relationship developed which resulted in Richard taking on the 'Head of Events' position in the Jigsaw Medical clinical team.

Once again this is a great step for Jigsaw in our event provision and a further 7 appointments over as many weeks have equally developed other areas of the business.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Building Foundations &amp; Growing The Team</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/building-foundations-growing-the-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 04 Jul 2015 11:04:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=791</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/image2.jpg"><img class="alignright wp-image-796 size-medium" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/image2-e1436007648376-225x300.jpg" alt="image" width="225" height="300" /></a>Our head office team has grown 6-fold since the beginning of the year.</h2>
I am sat with Sammie this morning (with my very glamorous peppermint tea!), discussing the latest members of the Jigsaw team. Although Sammie remains adamant that she "can't keep up" with it all, I am proud to say that nearly 20 amazing people have joined our head office team in just 7 months. Joining them are over 100 ambulance clinicians working on our own ambulances and over 3,000 Nurses, Ambulance Clinicians, Paramedics and Doctors - all of which I am proud to say are part of #TeamJigsaw.

After an exceptional start to 2015, we announced last week the appointment of Julie Mercer as our new Projects and Compliance Director. Julie joins Jigsaw Medical as a vastly experienced Director particularly within Project and Compliance leadership, and as a former Nurse and Operational Director for NHS Professionals she was responsible for the design, set up and implementation of the current “NHSP” organisation commissioned by the Department Of Health becoming the largest ‘in-house’ national temporary staff provider of the NHS. Before joining Jigsaw, she worked for a £500million recruitment business in a similar role, so not only can she do an amazing job, she is able to do it on a huge scale (which is exactly where we are hoping to be).

Along with Julie, we have recently had a further 7 members of the team join our head office in as many weeks. Richard McManus (who I wrote about in my <a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/event-season-underway/">post on the event season</a>) – is a Paramedic and former Medical Manager for events such as ‘V Festival’ and the ‘Tour de France’, he joins as Head of Events and will be responsible for leading our team of event managers to deliver and develop medical provision to some of the UK’s largest events.

Jon Shield has been appointed to lead our Specialist Operations Division, which is an exciting new division that will be launching in August 2015. As well as recently completing his Paramedic Degree, Jon has extensive military background serving in the Parachute Regiment, and has also worked in the private sector on Close Protection, Maritime and hostile environment deployments across the globe.

Furthermore, Sian Jeffery and Elliot Finney have joined Jigsaw as Recruitment Consultants to facilitate the growth within our recruitment division, and deal with the increasing demands faced of an ever expanding client-base. Additionally, Elinor Parry has joined our Training Division to facilitate the range of additional courses we are offering this year. Jan Pomfret joins our compliance team from a position with the UK Doctor's regulator, the GMC. Finally, Lisa Walker joins our Accounts &amp; Payroll team to support the day-to-day finance requirements and the payroll of thousands of people every week.
<h3>It's about foundations...</h3>
I was recently honoured to be asked to speak at a recent event hosted by <a href="http://www.ukfast.co.uk">UKFast</a>. Lawrence Jones (CEO of UKFast) asked me to join him and two other entrepreneurs to share our experiences for their #InspireMCR event. One thing struck me during Lawrence's talk was one analogy which really hit home with me and the strategy we so strongly adopted at Jigsaw - which was "the stronger your foundations, the higher your building will be".

Up until recently, both our compliance and accounts teams had more people in than our sales teams in any of our divisions. We could have easily taken on loads of great sales people between the beginning of the year and now, but we didn't. The reason? - because we wanted our foundations to be strong enough to support our huge plans for the coming years.

You will notice that many of these recent appointments are very much 'sales' focused because now we have those very strong foundations in place, we can really start to make an even bigger dint on the market than we already have.

No longer is Jigsaw Medical simply the vision of a 23 year old graduate Paramedic. We have inspirational people who share this vision. Our foundations consist of the very best people, in all of the right places. From an ex-CEO of a £580million group to management trainers. From Chartered Accountants to Consultant Anaesthetists, from vastly experienced NHS compliance Directors to the very best recruitment consultants, sales team, PR professionals, clinical educators and operational and clinical management professionals.

All of this makes #TeamJigsaw very special... the rest of 2015 and going into 2016 is going to be an awesome experience for everyone who is on-board the Jigsaw rocket ship!

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/4d3c1c5bf36fa.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-605" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/4d3c1c5bf36fa.jpg" alt="4d3c1c5bf36fa" width="600" height="445" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[638]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Everyone is talking about disruption</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/disruption/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jul 2015 15:11:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=798</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/disruption-300x196.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-799" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/disruption-300x196-300x196.jpg" alt="disruption-300x196" width="300" height="196" /></a>Everyone seems to be talking about 'disruption' at the moment, but what does it mean?</h2>
I've heard an increasing rumble about disruption over the last few months, in fact it was only a couple of weeks ago I looked into it properly, after I was told by our PR team at <a href="www.jigsawmedical.com">Jigsaw Medical</a> that Lawrence Jones (CEO at UKFast) had mentioned us in his speech at the "IOD Disruptor" conference in Manchester.

When I watched it back to make sure Lawrence was being nice about us (which I never doubted, for the record), there were some amazing 'takes' on disruption and how powerful it is in businesses, especially in this new world of huge technological capability and what seems to be a more enterprising culture than the past few years.

After a bit of digging, I noticed that Richard Branson had setup 'Virgin Disruptor's' with Holly (his daughter) which essentially debated areas of 'disruption' and focused on entrepreneurs being 'open minded' in order to become a 'disruptor'.

A <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/carolinehoward/2013/03/27/you-say-innovator-i-say-disruptor-whats-the-difference/">recent post by Forbes</a> claimed that people are sometimes confused about the difference between innovation and disruption. "It’s not exactly black and white, but there are real distinctions, and it’s not just splitting hairs." They said to "think of it this way: Disruptors are innovators, but not all innovators are disruptors — in the same way that a square is a rectangle but not all rectangles are squares"... (at this point, you have to stick with it).... Innovation and disruption are similar in that they are both makers and builders. Disruption takes a left turn by literally uprooting and changing how we think, behave, do business, learn and go about our day-to-day.
<h3>Do Jigsaw disrupt?</h3>
To be honest, I think we have done so since the beginning - without really knowing it. I'd like to say that we have started to change how private organisations within the healthcare sector operate and are perceived. Without going on forever, I can think of a few examples of how we have 'disrupted the market'. One example is being the only fully self-sufficient ambulance provider in the private sector, with the ability to educate internally right up to Paramedic degree level, including the relevant on-the-job training (the only company in that position). Another example would be to utilise Health Care Professionals in 'out of the box ways', such as putting Paramedics in operating theatres.

The vision for everyone in Jigsaw is big, it's to make a huge impact on the healthcare sector, with maximum quality healthcare in a creative and innovative way, embracing technology in the process.

That's the stamp we want to leave on the UK and eventually the world... so if that's what you call 'disruption' in the market, then I am proud to say we are 'disruptor's' (in the nicest possible way).]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How much money is success?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/how-much-money-is-success/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Aug 2015 10:07:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=803</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/CLoIoM5WcAA-A9_.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-804" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/CLoIoM5WcAA-A9_-286x300.jpg" alt="CLoIoM5WcAA-A9_" width="286" height="300" /></a>"Money is a byproduct of success"</h2>
You will often here this quote from entrepreneurs and it is certainly one I can relate to. Whilst everyone needs to earn a living, I like many entrepreneurs didn't start my business to "make lots of money" and in actual fact, I have never measured the success of Jigsaw in how much money we have been making, rather I use our level of revenue as a guide to see how we are growing.

Personally, I think a leader needs to be 'visionary' rather than exclusively money and performance focused, they need to see the 'bigger picture' and drive the 'purpose' of the business. I truly believe that if entrepreneurs hold this as a core value, the money will follow as a byproduct.
<h2>Does everyone need to forget about the money?</h2>
Absolutely not. Whilst it is vital for 'visionary' entrepreneurs to stay focused on the purpose and 'bigger picture', every business needs to make money to survive and in actual fact, they need the exact opposite to themselves in order to succeed.

Accountants clearly need to focus on the money, where it goes and make sure any business has enough of it to meet the vision of the leader - but this concept goes beyond them.

In Jigsaw, I would classify myself as 'visionary' rather than money focused, I would rather spend money on making Jigsaw better, than putting it in my personal bank account. However, without my money driven counter parts in our Sales and Recruitment teams - nothing would ever happen! Equally, we need the Clinical teams to be focused on quality, rather than money and so they are not afraid of getting the latest equipment. It is this blend which has got Jigsaw to where it is.
<h2>So is "Money is a byproduct of success"?</h2>
Absolutely. But only when you have the right blend of people, with their own reasons for doing what they are doing - which does actually include, in the likes of our recruitment &amp; sales teams, them being money focused.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>803</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-08-05 10:07:06]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-08-05 10:07:06]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="money"><![CDATA[money]]></category>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="success"><![CDATA[success]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Leadership - What makes a good leader?</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/leadership-what-makes-a-good-leader/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 18 Aug 2015 12:56:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=808</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>With the Labour leadership campaign representing a large proportion of the national media coverage at the moment I thought it would be a good time to write an article about leadership.</h3>
Don't worry I'm not going to write an article about politics, and whilst I don't agree with Jeremy Corbyn on quite a few of his policies there does seem to be some distinct reasons as to why he is garnering so much support and momentum, and those reasons can be easily applied to leading in the work place.
<h3>1) Honesty</h3>
Whether it be business or politics, being open and honest is a key attribute of a good leader. Here at #TeamJigsaw I always do my best to be honest with all of my team, irrespective of their level in the 'hierarchy', about the performance and direction of the company. The team are a direct reflection of myself and the company so if I am honest and ethical with them, they will follow suit, and that will come across to clients and customers alike.
<h3>2) Communication</h3>
I am very clear what I want to achieve with Jigsaw and much of it is a shared vision of where we want to be. Ultimately that is to be the best supplier of medical staff and clinical / healthcare services in the world, whilst also providing the highest quality of care to our customer, clients and ultimately the patients. At #TeamJigsaw there are no secrets. All of the team know exactly what we want to achieve and having these defined goal helps us all work towards it with more confidence.
<h3>3) Passion</h3>
Like the above I am extremely passionate about Jigsaw Medical and the quality of care we provide, particularly to patients that our ambulance crews and medical staff deal with on a day-to-day basis. I'm not backwards in coming forwards in sharing and conveying my passion and what we want to achieve, and I think this helps other members of #TeamJigsaw buy into the ethos of the company. Well we've never had a member of staff leave so we must be doing something right!
<h3>4) Commitment</h3>
If you want people to work hard for you and your company you must put the work in yourself and lead by example. I'm usually one of the first in the office in the morning and one of the last out in the evening. I believe that people see my commitment to the cause and I like to think that this motivates people to do the same. Additionally, I am committed to making Jigsaw House and our other 5 offices an enjoyable place to come to everyday, which helps keep morale and motivation high within the company, and in turn helps people deliver the highest quality of work possible.
<h3>5) Optimism</h3>
This is possibly my favourite and the most important. A leader has to be optimistic. The best leaders in the world and particularly the ones who have inspired me (Richard Branson and Lawrence Jones) are some of the most optimistic people you will ever meet. They're always a source of positive energy and you can see a reflection of them in the staff that work for them. When there is a problem at Jigsaw I don't dwell on the problems but always try to provide a positive solution and find the right things to do to inspire and reassure.

Obviously there are countless other attributes that contribute to being a good leader, the above list is not the be all and end all. My team may tell you differently (I hope not!!) but I like to think I'm doing a good job at leading #TeamJigsaw in the right direction. However, there isn't one right answer, you have to be able to constantly learn and evolve, but if you're successful and your team support you, you're probably doing it right!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>42 under 42...</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/42-under-42/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Oct 2015 08:34:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=818</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/42_u_42_logo.jpg"><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-819" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/42_u_42_logo.jpg" alt="42_u_42_logo" width="160" height="105" /></a>Every year Insider Media publish their '42 Under 42' list...</h2>
This year, I am super proud to have been included in the <a href="http://www.insidermedia.com/insider/north-west/148763-insider-reveals-42-under-42-list/">class of 2015</a>, this is certainly testament to the efforts of the whole of #TeamJigsaw, both in our HQ, regional offices and of course the Paramedics, Doctors, Nurses and Ambulance Clinician's we have out treating patients across the UK.

Chris Maguire, editor of <em>North West Business Insider</em>, said: "These are the people who we feel are the ones to watch. The class of 2015 is packed full of inspirational entrepreneurs. Age has been no barrier to their success and we congratulate them all."

I am proud to be the youngest on the list this year, but the fact remains that it is not "me" who has secured a place on this prestigious list - I am simply accepting it on behalf of the whole of #TeamJigsaw who have got us to where we are today - so thank you!

<em>North West Business Insider</em>'s 42 Under 42 list is sponsored by Saffery Champness and the University of Bolton.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Incredible 6 months at Jigsaw Medical!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/incredible-6-months-at-jigsaw-medical/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Dec 2015 15:56:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=827</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>2015 has been a special year for Jigsaw Medical but the final 6 months have been particularly impressive with multi-million-pound investment, life-saving treatment and unprecedented growth.</h3>
Since June, Jigsaw Medical have added over 30 brand new fully-kitted ambulances to the already expansive fleet as well as 8 brand new response vehicles that help supplement the ambulances clinically. In order to house the new vehicles, multiple operational offices have been established across the UK that act as bases for crew members to work from in a whole host of different areas.

As well as operational expansion, Jigsaw medical has always been a keen “Investor in People” and in the previous 6 months, the head office (Jigsaw House) in Tarporley has seen 8 new people successfully join the team with 2 new members set to join the New Year.

The last 6 months have also seen 2 new Directors join the company; Julie Mercer joined the team in late summer as Projects and Compliance Director. Julie joined Jigsaw Medical as a vastly experienced Director particularly within Project and Compliance leadership within the NHS. Additionally, Richard McManus was appointed Director of Clinical Services in July (after previously holding the Head of Events position) and brought with him a wealth of medical and event organisation experience.

Richard stated: “It’s been an eventful but ultimately extremely fruitful end to 2015. With over 600 clinicians successfully registering and becoming fully compliant in that period. Coupled with over £3 million invested in gold standard equipment and vehicles we have managed to amass in excess of 250,000 hours worked by the Jigsaw team.”

“And in that period, with the expertise, knowledge and equipment that our crews are armed with, as well as other key performance indicators, we have been responsible for 8 ROSCs (Return of Spontaneous Circulation) and the safe delivery of at least 5 babies. Without the incredible investment and team that we have at Jigsaw none of that would have been possible.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>827</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-12-15 15:56:39]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-12-15 15:56:39]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[incredible-6-months-at-jigsaw-medical]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="business"><![CDATA[Business]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="jigsaw-medical"><![CDATA[Jigsaw Medical]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[829]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_post_layout]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[fullwidth]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_sidebar_use]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Default Sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wip_theme_faturedimage_on_single]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[slide_template]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What a year it&#039;s been!</title>
		<link>http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/what-a-year-its-been/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 Dec 2015 12:55:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/?p=832</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>As 2015 comes to a close, its time to reflect on the year that's passed and set goals for the year ahead...</h3>
For me, 2015 has been an incredible year - fast paced to say the least. In just one year we have grown over 500% on the previous year which is all thanks to our amazing team and of course our clients. 2015 has seen over 2,200 new clinicians registering to work with Jigsaw Medical, we have invested over £3 million in gold standard equipment and vehicles we have managed to amass in excess of 750,000 hours worked by the Jigsaw team... our Ambulance crews have even delivered over 10 babies into the world!

On a personal level, it has been amazing to continue to build our leadership team and see Jigsaw, in just 4 years, going from the University bedroom startup it once was, to a multi-million pound business.
<h4><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/teamjigsaw.png"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-836" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/teamjigsaw-300x60.png" alt="teamjigsaw" width="300" height="60" /></a>My very own New Year's Honors List....</h4>
The 'Jigsaw Medical' we have today is only here because of the team and those who have helped me (and the business) along the journey so far, I would like to thank absolutely all of the team who are such a massive part of Jigsaw in their own ways and in their respective divisions....
<ul>
	<li>To the Directors who keep everything (including me) in check - I don't know what I would do without these amazing guys!</li>
	<li>The Jigsaw House; recruitment, compliance, finance, training, clinical, operations and communications teams</li>
	<li>To the Area Operations teams who keep our operational bases running smoothly 24/7</li>
	<li>Our Clinical Governance Team who make sure our patients get the very best clinical care</li>
	<li>Our Fleet Engineers who work 24/7 keeping our vehicles on the road</li>
	<li>... and of course; the Paramedics, Emergency Care Assistants, Technicians, Nurses and Doctors who represent Jigsaw and deliver this exceptional care to our patients... you are all amazing and without you, there would be no Jigsaw!</li>
</ul>
Along with our own team, I would like to thank our suppliers for keeping us well stocked in 2015 (specifically <a href="http://www.spservices.co.uk">SP Services</a>) and all those organisations who continue to support Jigsaw's growth. I would also like to thank all those who continue to support me personally through guidance, mentorship and support; including my family (Mum, Dad &amp; Sister, Rob, Laurie and of course Sammie!) and last but not least... <a href="http://www.lawrencejones.eu/">Lawrence Jones </a>for the mentorship, support, guidance and inspiration! - I cannot begin to tell you all how much of a difference this has made!
<h4><a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/2016-new-year-ss-1920.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-835" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/2016-new-year-ss-1920-300x169.jpg" alt="2016-new-year-ss-1920" width="300" height="169" /></a>Into 2016...</h4>
We have some big - in fact, very big plans for 2016. Whilst I am so proud of growing over 500% this year, the plans for 2016 will see this be even higher compared with this year. However, as a fast growing business, we have learn't many lessons and we have had to adapt to demand and continue to improve, innovate and make things better - this is something we will continue as an ethos into 2016.

We have a continuous recruitment drive to support several new contracts starting in early 2016 and we hope to expand even more across the UK, particularly in strengthening our ambulance operations (so if you are reading this and fancy a new challenge in 2016, <a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/contact-chris/">get in touch</a>!). To further support this, we will build many more brand new, gold-standard vehicles for our crews to work with. Our clinical governance team will continue to drive clinical innovations and continue to hold our patients and the very forefront of what we do.
<h4>Tomorrow is the start of your 365 page book....</h4>
(When I posted this amazing quote on Twitter this morning, within 40seconds I was corrected... 2016 is of course a leap-year, so you actually get 366!!)

<a href="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/CXjGGw4WQAArmSZ1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-834" src="http://www.chrispercival.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/CXjGGw4WQAArmSZ1-300x240.jpg" alt="CXjGGw4WQAArmSZ" width="300" height="240" /></a>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">What are your goals for 2016?... what is written in your book?</h3>
<h2 style="text-align: center;">Have an amazing New Year's eve and I will see you all in 2016!</h2>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
